physDesc.p: The letter consists of three sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. In the upper left of the first page, “Aldington” is written in pencil. In the upper right of every page there is a date, and in the upper left of all pages except the first is the page number.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have not recovered yet from your letter which came yesterday. I cannot bear to have you go to the war! But, of course, it must be, and I can only hope from the bottom of my heart that you, and Flint, and Lawrence all come back unscathed, and feeling that you have gained something by what is, after all, a great experience.

How can they take Lawrence? I thought he was very ill with consumption. What will they do with him when they get him? I should not think he could last long in the trenches! Fletcher sent me out Hilda’s letter to him to read, and I must say I think she is awfully plucky. Perhaps she is right to stay in England. I am sure I would do the same if I were in her place. But, of course, I wish she were here.

Fletcher has probably told you that he is sailing for England very soon. I do not think he has decided how long he will be gone. But it leaves me terribly alone, and I feel very blue about it. And this, added to your letter, is a hard thing to stand up under.

I am sorry he told you about my plan for your being English correspondent of Braithwaite’s paper. I had spoken to Braithwaite about it long ago, and he told me that he wanted very much to have you and would write to you himself. I preferred to have him write to you himself, as then the thing would be official. If he has not already done so, it is presumably because he does not feel able to pay for the articles yet. My suggestion was that he take you on as English correspondent at a yearly salary, so much a month. I have spoken to him about it several times, and he has always professed his interest and said that he was going to write at once. I will speak to him again tonight and try and get something more definite. But I had such an experience in suggesting a tentative scheme when we thought of getting up a paper ourselves, that I was not going to say anything to you about it until it was decided, so as not to raise any hopes which I had no power to fulfill. As Fletcher has told you, however, I may say that I think I can work the arrangement in the end. I shall certainly try to, very hard. And I think Hilda’s suggestion for managing it while you are away is all right.

You must not forget, dear Richard, that even in the trenches one is not dead. Plenty of books are being published from the trenches all the time. They have a kind of vicarious and romantic interest through being written by men on active duty. Houghton & Mifflin have just published some awful things by a man named Frankau in their Poetry Series, called “Songs of the Guns”. Their interest lies purely in the fact that the man is in the artillery and writing about what he knows. It is bad Kiplingesque stuff, but I imagine it sells well in England. It is not doing anything here.

I want you to feel that although the ocean separates us, nothing else ever does or can, and that Hilda can always turn to me for anything at any time. I wish I could come over and see you before you start for the front. It hurts me very much to feel that this cannot be. But I am not in Fletcher’s position. If I go abroad I am obliged to take other people with me, and I do not think it right to endanger other lives on the high seas at present unless absolutely necessary; and of course it is not.
I suppose it will take you some months to be trained before you can leave England. So I am sure that the Anthology will reach you some time as I sent it two weeks ago. I do hope you will like it.
If you want to send some poems to me, I have no doubt that I can get Braithwaite to take them.

Do write to me often and keep me posted as to all that goes on with you, and how Flint and Lawrence are. If you go into an officer’s corps I do not suppose that you will see much of them; but I hope you will know something about them. I shall write to Hilda constantly about anything and everything, and try to make her feel a little bit as though I were dropping in. And if she ever decides to come to America, please let her consider that she can come directly to me while she is deciding what to do. I wish she would come from the bott om of my heart.

Good luck, dear Richard. I cannot help feeling that the war is nearing its conclusion, and I only pray that it will be over before you get there. I shall write constantly, if you will give me an address. With a great deal of love,

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: Mr. Braithwaite has told me that I might write to you officially, as he is so busy, and ask you if you will supply him with a monthly letter about poetical affairs in England, and, if possible, in Paris. This would be about 1200 words, for which he is willing to pay $5.00 a month.

He wants it partly literary and partly commercial, by which I mean he wants to know what books of poetry are being published, as well as what are being written, and of poetical events of importance. This is to be written entirely without bias of school or point of view; merely with a view to mentioning these things that are good enough to be mentioned, no matter under what banner the author has enlisted himself. Mr. Braithwaite is trying to make his paper quite eclectic–to run it, as he expresses it, as an open forum. Of course, you and I do not approve of this, but I think that his paper is worth writing for, as it apparently has a certain sale. They printed 4,000 copies of the first number, as I think I wrote you.

Should you feel like undertaking this job, please write to him direct –
Mr. William Stanley Braithwaite 27 Ellsworth Avenue Cambridge, Mass. U.S.A.
I have told him that I would collect the money and send it to you, because I think if you wait for him to pay, you may wait quite a long time, as he is very unbusinesslike; and Lebowich, the other editor, is very much of a Jew. However, they paid me promptly for my poem last month, and I really do not anticipate any trouble, for Braithwaite is a thoroughly good fellow.

In Hilda’s letter to Fletcher, which he let me read, she says that in case you cannot do the letter yourself she thinks that she can work it up for you; and I think she could. Only bear in mind that they must have an all-around acquaintance with what is going on, and that your communication will be more along the lines of a bulletin than an article, although they want you to connect your news with remarks and criticisms – you know the style in which all foreign correspondents do. He wants to give his readers a little of the feeling as if they were in London or Paris and he could keep up with things. He would write you himself, as I have just said, only he has an immense amount of writing to do; and although he means to get round to it, sometimes he gets fearfully delayed. This is really true, for the man is not only editor of the “Poetry Review”, but poetical editor of the “Transcript”, editor and compiler of the “Magazine Anthology”; and the correspondence and people asking him questions about poetry is enormous, and he cannot afford a secretary. So that I think you can take this authorization from me as being as good as a letter from him, particularly as I am getting from him a signed acknowledgement of it.
